page.title: 03Farming In Norton Area.
page.content: {Crops. }The arable crops were on the flatter land, but the permanent grass was mainly in the brook and river valleys. When the farmers grow their crops, they plant beet, wheat then potatoes. When they have a field of grass for mowing they call it a ley. They keep this for three or four years for silage or hay, then plough it up again, spreading farmyard manure before planting potatoes on it. In the summer they cut the grass, put it in the silage pit, then cover it with a black polythene sheet with tyres to hold it on. The grass for hay is cut before it goes to seed, is left to dry, then is turned, baled and stored in barns. We saw round and rectangular bales. In winter the silage and hay are fed to the animals.
